segments.text: Okay, let's go.
Okay, I'm ready.
Enough about 2001 nights.
Now, first of all, I should like to know what interested you in oceanography.
Specifically, you mean?
Specifically, yeah.
Well, my first real involvement in oceanography was during World War II with surf and beaches.
working out of the University of California on landing craft, performance of waves, depths.
That was my first actual scientific involvement, 1945, I guess, 44, or thereabouts.
More generally, of course, I'd been interested in oceanography or in the oceans quite a long time before that.
I was a commercial fisherman for three years off the Oregon coast and
always was since childhood was interested in the oceans and got a great thrill out of fishing in a surf or off the boat or out of a skiff.
When were you a commercial fisherman?
About 1936 to 39.
I have you at Oregon State University from 30 to 41.
That's about right.
Took me about that long to get through.
But I don't have you receiving a degree.
I didn't.
I got a degree at Berkeley.
That's right.
What did you do at Oregon State University?
Oh, I took things as long as I could stand it, and then did something else.
I joined and went in the Forestry Service, worked in the Three C's, the Resettlement Administration, worked as a logger, went fishing, then go back to school.
Fortunately, I sort of kept up my academic record there at reasonably respectable levels.
It was a
It was a good experience because it allowed me to take all kinds of different subjects, which I always felt I profited from.
Engineering, science, literature.
Much better, I think, than in my particular case, than going straight through school in some sort of rigorous curriculum.
Was it economic pressure or the depression that sent you to these various jobs, or was it just wanderlust?
I was all three plus my poor handling of my finances at various times, such finances as they were possible in those days.
And did you primarily concentrate on science while you were at Oregon State or just?
Yeah, science, math, I took quite a bit of literature, history, paleontology, engineering,
chemistry, chemical engineering.
Do you think this sort of broad education is necessary for scientists?
I think this kind of broad education is essential if we're going to solve our problems.
We have to have both penetrating minds and broadly comprehensive ones.
People who have broad interests
And I would take exception to your point, education, because I think a person who's broadly interested will educate themselves into these broader areas.
But the whole idea that science is going to make its breakthroughs and understanding of the universe and man's position in it from narrow approaches versus is balderdash.
It's got to have both, narrowly penetrating approaches and very broadly comprehensive ones.
Science, of course, has capitalized the last few centuries on taking things apart.
And now it's clear the problem of putting things together.
And that's going to take people who have looked at all the parts spread around the floor, you see.
We're much in the position of a 12-year-old stating the TV apart on the kitchen floor, you know, without seeing quite how it was together in the first place in our science.
I noticed when you go to Berkeley, you major in engineering.
That's what your degree is, a BS in engineering.
The fastest degree I could get.
Oh, okay.
Was there such a thing as marine engineering then?
No, no, no.
Well, there was marine engineering, but that's boat building type of thing.
Old-fashioned marine engineering, yeah.
No, I took civil.
Okay.
And expediency steered you in this direction?
No, I had...
The reason I took engineering is early in the war, just before the war, I took a job as surveyor on a big naval base and rather rapidly became the chief engineer without any engineering training.
And this interested me quite a bit, several factors.
First, engineering was interesting, which is only applied physics, really.
And secondly, the fact I could
do that well without any formal engineering training seemed to me to indicate that that might be my fork.
And so I thought, why not get an engineering degree from the best engineering school?
So I did so.
What were your career goals when you received an engineering degree?
My career goals were to do...
I mean, when I did that, I thought I was going to be an engineer.
I truly did.
My grandfather had been an engineer and
charge of the Harriman lines, chief engineer for the Harriman lines.
My father had been chief engineer for the Canadian Pacific.
And I'd always been told I was going to be an engineer, and I always had resented it and refused to consider it.
And at this time, I decided, yeah, that's what I'm going to be.
Then when I went out looking for a job, they all sounded
being the sectional engineer at Dunsmuir or something like that.
I went back and asked Dean O'Brien if I couldn't do some research in the engineering department, and that's where I got started on the waves, beaches, and surf.
Oh, okay.
That's where I first met Ravel, too.
Where, here?
No, on the waves, beaches, and surf.
Oh, okay.
That's what he said.
I was shocked all of a sudden when you introduced him.
Something that didn't work out.
Do you ever regret having not taken a higher degree?
Do I ever regret it?
No, I don't think so.
I'm often told to make sure I never get one because it's a phenomenon to have somebody and not have one, you see.
Do you think failure to earn one has limited your career, if I may use that word?
I don't know.
I haven't really thought about it a hell of a lot.
It's never worried me anyway.
Let me try it a different way.

Does it seem to you as if the movement towards professional degrees since World War II, when in effect graduate degrees have become essential to the various academic professions, do you think that's potentially a mistake?
Well, I think I would have progressed farther and accomplished less, or I could have progressed farther by accomplishing less, let me say, if I'd had a higher degree there.
statement.
Yeah.
No, what strikes me is there are all kinds of historians and scientists who come out of World War II with either no degrees or BA degrees who accomplish a great deal.
That ends someplace in the 50s as society becomes more technical.
And yet, in a way, it doesn't seem to be as creative now as it once was.
Would you agree with that?
Well, I don't know.
The pros and cons about the higher degrees, it tends to be a document that is an entree, of course.
And I one time had a student who was, I thought, quite dull.
And I tried to persuade him to forget and get a higher degree.
And he said, you mean all those five years of work is wasted?
And I said, you mean you didn't learn anything?
I said, what were you doing?
It can't be wasted.
And he stopped for a minute, and then he said the most intelligent thing he's ever said.
He says, you know, Dr. Isaacs, which was an interesting statement in itself, I'm just not smart enough to get anywhere without a PhD.
And he wasn't, that's for sure.
So you see, the PhD, it seems to me, and the higher degrees have their pros and cons associated with them.

now i want to break away from chronology for a second and i want you to describe and give the significance of these things i've listed good heavens okay and uh and now first of all before i begin where did as an engineer were you asked to solve specialized problems is this what accounts for this list of inventions or
As a matter of fact, did these come to you?
You're telling me now that you're going to give me a list of inventions.
Yes, that's right.
No, I always selected my own problems first.
And people didn't come to you with research problems and say, how would you as an engineer solve this?
Sometimes.
Sometimes, all right.
Sure.
Well, if that happened in the process.
Folks came to me and asked me about how you'd make a mid-water trawl frame.
Right.
Well, if that occurred in the process of mentioning these, would you explain who came to you and what were the circumstances, too, involved?
Sure.
Good heavens, that sounds like an endless list.
No, I only listed 12 or 13, just not all of them, as a matter of fact.
1945, a device for traversing surf zones and beaches.
Oh.
Well, I was working then on amphibious craft and several aspects.
How in the devil did you get a line out through these tremendous surfs of Northern California and Oregon and Washington?
Well, you could shoot one out.
And I would watch during the war boats come in, land on the beach, get broadside, swamped, and somebody trying to get a line through to pull them off or help them one way or another.
And they get broached and swamped and so forth.
So wouldn't it be nice if you could just send a line out?
Now, wouldn't it be nice if you could put something in the surface that would take an instrument out there so you could measure the waves, or put a rod on it and measure the surface?
So it's obvious that waves have plenty of power to do this kind of thing.
So you make a flap, and you rectify the wave so that the forces are only out, and you put it together.
And he said, no, nobody came to me on that one, of course.
Okay.
Does your work with this lead you later on to working with...
Wave power, wave propulsion, sure.
Sure, years later.
Also understanding something about undertow and worrying about sand motion, quite a few things.
All right.
And this began in effect from a military project.
Yeah, a military project of understanding amphibious craft.
Okay.
Would you...
adjudge the military, if I may say that, to play a sizable role in the development and advancement of oceanography in this period?
Well, of course.
The ONR, which was Revelle's baby, was, of course, a powerful influence and a very, very valuable one.
One of the best sponsors of research that ever existed.
I was also thinking possibly about experience gained in things like in anti-submarine warfare, for example, in anti-mine activities.
Sure.
A lot of those things have worked out.
You really have to look at the environment of a submarine.
And this gives you, I think, requires considerable thought into just exactly what is the meaning of placing this object in the ocean and its influences on it.
Some of that, of course, classified material.

the mine itself, the object on the bottom, the manner in which scour takes place, the release of particles, the release of bubbles, the influence, the collections of fish around it as part of the biological response to this object.
All these things are involved.
are part of beginning to build up a model of how the ocean puts together, even though they are directed towards a specific military need, I think.

If you look at them not as a highly specified task, but rather as, from the broader standpoint of here as an object within the natural environment, how does it make its presence known and what are its influences?
Then, of course, if you look at it that way, it has not just the military limitation.
ONR allowed you to do these sorts of things.
It was one of the most... ONR, I think, was one of the freest and most valuable types of sponsorship that oceanography has ever had.
Do you think ONR is more mission-oriented now than it was then?
Oh, sure.
Sure, I think so.
I hardly know what it...
supply kind of very little contact with it.
I think it's gotten very mission-oriented.
Is there any particular explanation for that?
Oh, I think the whole United States has never kind of quite recovered from the more bangs for a buck or how many philosophy.
That is, a fixed objective towards which you progress
It never allows for the unexpected to emerge, does it?
The unexpected is almost always more valuable than the expected, because expected is something you obviously know can exist.
Unexpected can be unlimited in its importance.
What about the magnesium rod release device in 1947?
Oh, heavens.
I was trying to make a pressure gauge for measuring waves in deep water and did so, but I needed to load it in cockets.
After it got to depth, I needed to open up a reservoir so it flooded with gas, and I needed something that was simple that would release it.
And Dean O'Brien said to me, as a matter of fact, Dean O'Brien, the head of the engineering school at Berkeley, said to me,
Why don't you look into magnesium?
It makes a good little battery with steel or brass.
And so I put it together, and it looked fine.
Just held the valve open with a magnesium wire, and after an easily calculable time, it released.
And that all led into looking at magnesium batteries and magnesium as its power source.
OK. That's what I wanted to know.
OK. What about the torpedo net in 1947?
Yeah.
Yeah, that was a more or less specific project.
And that was one of the few projects I ever worked with what was then the Bureau of Yards and Docks, I think, in which they had a great deal of trouble with torpedo nets tearing apart.
Well, a torpedo net is a very strange object.
manner in which trash is distributed through it is complicated.

But more particularly, that was the first hint I had of what's more recently developed into several things called, for instance, the breakwater, in that these big net floats behave very curiously in the sea.
And they behave very curiously because they were non-Archimedean bodies, to use the word improperly.
bodies on the sea surface that had much more displacement than they had mass and free to move with.
So they were forced to move in an exaggerated fashion.
And this is one of the reasons that the torpedo nets were torn apart, because the floats were driven by something other than the orbital velocities of the waves.
And this put them out of phase with the net that they were supporting.
And this is the first hint I got of, as you begin to get larger and larger things in the ocean, accelerated forces play the more dominant role than surface forces.
Does this end up later on then also involved in the energy project?
Oh, sure.
Yeah.
Well, does it also end up...
The principal thing you see is,
something that is a concept which other people have probably understood much better than I have.
But as you go to these larger and larger objects in a varying pressure field, like a wave, the smaller objects are driven by drag, ordinary drag forces, hydrodynamic drag.
And then
Even though you keep everything symmetrical and you merely scale it up into larger and larger dimensions, there's one aspect, and that's the accelerated forces, that scales on a one-to-one basis.
That is, the forces are always equal to the volume.
In other words, the dimension to the third power.
where its surface forces go like the dimension squared.

And thus, when you begin to get into very large objects, but not too large objects, in the wave field, such as the big lakes or the Texas Towers, an offshore crewing platform, it's clear that they're driven far more by the accelerated forces, which act on the total volume of them, than by the surface forces.
And you might well forget the surface forces.
And these are aspects that are still forgotten.

For instance, in these big OTEC programs, where you're starting to put very large, slow-moving things in the ocean for ocean thermal energy conversion, the people and very erudite people at APL and Lockheed just totally forgot the fact that they're mainly dealing with accelerations, inertial forces.
rather than the ordinary, conventional, frictional hydrodynamic dragons.
And so they've made some mistakes.
See, one thing scales like the square of the dimensions.
The other scales like the cube of the dimensions.
And even though it's a trivial effect at very small dimensions, it becomes a dominant on a very large dimension, since it's going up like the cube.
You've been out in the desert, and you've seen these great boulders as big as a room that are way out in the desert somewhere?
Yes.
How'd they get there?
They're obviously carried there by water.
Well, at the moment that a flood wave hits a boulder like that, the crest of a flood wave hits a boulder, the boulder is easily moved as a sand grain.
Because, you see, it's now at that moment subject to volume forces that scale just exactly like its weight.
For frictional forces, it didn't care less.
Once the flood flow is established, the boulder sits there.
It's like a lead toad, of course.
But at that instant, when the crest comes, it's as easily moved as a sand grain.
So for an instance, it's moved.
And a succession of these, and out it is, out in the desert, miles away.
You can't conceive of how it got there.
This is all part of the same phenomenology.
And I think it's an interesting one.
And I believe I've capitalized on it in a couple of cases.
That came from the submarine net problem, yes.
OK. And what about the thermopile wave meter?
Well, I watched these.
These are all very old things.
That was a special problem, I think.
I wanted to see.
if we couldn't establish a very simple wave measuring device that could be put out to sea simply by a landing craft, dropped by a landing craft.
So a beach master trying to bring landing craft in through the surf could observe the oncoming waves before they became breakers.
on a meter of some sort on the beach and guide the landing craft into the lower breakers to come to the surf zone.
Now, it didn't need to be exact.
All it needed to be was relative correct.
He would see big waves coming in.
He'd see the breakers.
He'd know they couldn't survive that.
And then he'd see a series of lower waves coming in.
And he could beckon them in at that point, see, or vector them in with a radio.

It was the simplest device I could think of, a bag of gas that's adiabatically heated and cooled by the wave pressure in there and a simple little thermopile inside, up against sea water on conductive to sea water on the other side to make the cold junction or the reference junction.
And it just responded to the waves.
And he could see the high ones, and he could see the low ones.
That's all he had to see.
He didn't have to know how high they were.
He knew that the big ones were producing wave breakers that
He didn't want his craft to be in, and you could tell him to retract or to dander at the optimum times.
That was the purpose of that whole thing.
All right.
What about the Isaac's Kid Midwater Troll?
There's a case where Dr. Hubbs came to me, and he won.

a net to really take the run deep fast and take the bath pelagic fish and Lou Kidd and I worked on that and I must say I think we lucked out on that one because it's always been a bit strange to me that we cut that we got that net hung we got that diving vane made
We got the bridles cut, and we took it out to sea, and immediately we filled beautifully, dove beautifully, went down deep, and we could tow it at three, four thousand meters at reasonable speeds.
Even today, if those bridles are cut a few inches different, the damn thing doesn't work.
I never understood.
We could have been so discouraged, we'd never have followed it through.
And I see that thing all over the world, and that bridle is right to the same inch.
And it was pretty much of a thrill, really, in those days.
I remember those days quite well.
On our first trips out, we would make halls that would,
increased the number of specimens of some rare fish in the museums of the world by 50.
You know, one haul.
When there had only been 10 in all the museums of the world, we get 500 of the things.
And of course, then specimen after specimen, it was totally unidentified.
It was quite a thrill.
We made a 20-foot one one time, rammed it into the bottom through an axe and a parlous.
Took one of the greatest mid-bottom trawls that anybody ever took.
Rare brachiopods and glass sponges.
That's probably considered in terms of oceanography your most important and famous invention.
Would you agree with that?
Oh, I don't.
I wouldn't try to judge it.

It certainly has been very broadly spread around the world, and I kind of suffer from it to some extent because I go to some outlandish place, and that's what I'm known for, you see, the Isaac Kidd Midwether Tronc.
Well, I'm really trying to edge your question until you're unfairly, so let me ask you directly.
That is, if...
you should like to name what you consider your major accomplishment, what would you name?
You mean something specific?
Something specific, yeah.
If you just wanted, you know, it was always said John Adams wanted such and such card upon his tombstone.
If you just had to be remembered for one thing, what would you like to be remembered for?
Oh, good heavens, I'd hate to be remembered for one thing.
Well, I'd rather think this whole approach of this
Dynamic breakwater is going to be a considerable breakthrough.
I think it's going to revolutionize the whole method of defending ourselves against the destructive influences of waves, beach erosion, harbors.
I think it has the potential of allowing the defense of our eroding coastlines.

of protecting structures offshore, of making harbors of refuge in the open sea, of protecting small beaches and fishing villages in remote places in a way that can be afforded, so that people can pull their primitive boats out over the beach and get themselves some fish.
make swimming beaches in places where surf now makes it essentially impossible, and on and on.
There's quite a different approach to harbor protection, for example, than these damn Robomon breakwater
And of course, it's totally the opposite direction.
It's interesting to conceive that no matter how long you developed a rubble mound breakwater, you'd never come up with the idea of putting the lightest possible thing in the ocean.
And it takes a 180 degree shift to do that.
And it works on a different principle.
I think maybe that's it.
I expect to see the iceberg really solve some problems.
I think the Israelis would do it now.
They don't really have the money.
But they would do it, except the minimum iceberg they could bring is too big.
It covers the whole damn state with three feet of water.
The Arabs are going to do it, or so I've announced.
And it certainly is a natural one for them.
The US is too followed up, I think, to do anything quite so dramatic.
